in-person seminar or other discussion format

comments: I also attended many virtual one-on-one office hours
None

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to write a better academic paper and how to analyze how history is presented through nonfiction texts.

In this course, we write four papers with different focuses. We read and analyzed chapters that each considered different components of history and how history is represented. We used these ideas in the context of different historical events, then carried out a research paper about an event or period of our choice. I learned about writing extensive papers at the college level, and how to look at history through a different lens.
I developed better academic writing skills and habits. I was able to correct some of my deficiencies when it comes to academic research and writing.

I developed my skills in synthesizing information and critically analyzing them to form more coherent and persuasive arguments that were backed up by research and reasoning. In general, I learned to catch and comprehend subtle arguments in readings and to write better essays.
I improved my writing by making more concise arguments and putting more thought into the structure of my papers.
Presenting an argument, library search, fictional writing

I felt like the course was very good for developing all kinds of writing skills. We wrote four essays over the course of the semester: rhetorical analysis, synthesis, research, and historical fiction. I felt like each one allowed me to build a different writing skill, resulting in a lot of overall improvement.

Through this class, I learned how to master college-level writing: crafting intros and conclusions, creating effective transitions between paragraphs, and establishing motives for my papers, for example. I also improved my argumentative skills, and I learned how to more effectively analyze the implications and nuances of my arguments. Also, I learned to view the world as a collection of storiesstories that, by their very nature, require subjective and often arbitrary choices to create and interpret.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course's strengths were its pace, great instructor, and its interesting reading material.

I really enjoyed this course. Prof Ringel-Ensley is really engaged and gave us great feedback with every draft of each paper. Also, I enjoyed the peer review process that we went through to get feedback from students in class. If I could change anything, I would want a little bit more guidance in the planning stages of the paper - I feel like often we brought in our first draft and were on our own to discuss ideas/approaches. However, office hours were very helpful for this.
The content was really interesting and honestly changed my entire perception of history as a whole. Some of the readings were a bit dense or dull at times, but overall I liked the course!

This course was well-structured, and I felt that I learned a lot from all the essays we had to write, especially the ones that required multiple revisions. The class sessions devoted to peer-editing our drafts were especially helpful, and the one-on-one office hours also helped me greatly improve my writing skills.
I think the workload of this course was consistent with the progression of the semester. The only thing that could improve it would be having in-person classes.
I enjoyed the lively in-class discussions.

I felt like the course was just very good overall at improving writing across many disciplines. I felt like one of the weaknesses was that the discussions were sometimes difficult to get into, but much of that can likely be attributed to the virtual environment.

Strengths: excellent professor, interesting material, a great intro to college-level writing

Weaknesses: besides being on Zoom (which obviously couldnt have been helped) I cant think of any weaknesses!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think Prof Ringel-Ensley's use of breakout rooms was very helpful. I know breakout rooms have a bad reputation for being awkward and unhelpful, but I really valued the time that we had in breakout rooms to discuss readings and review drafts. I think she did the best she could to have the small seminar environment in a virtual setting.
This was the only class where I enjoyed breakout rooms. I also liked having virtual office hours. This course had no weaknesses.
No specific COVID-19 measures
I thought that Prof. Ringel-Ensley made very effective use of breakout rooms.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are interested in learning how to write a college-level paper and are interested in perspectives on history, then this writing seminar is for you.

Yes! This course was a great introduction to writing at the college level. In high school, I wrote a lot of short essays but few long papers. This course was very helpful in making me feel more comfortable writing more extensive papers and using the resources at the Yale libraries. This was a great course and I would definitely encourage others to take it.
Yes! It was really interesting.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I wasn't sure whether or not I would like this class going into it, but I soon found that my writing skills greatly improved throughout the course.
I would definitely recommend this course to any other student, regardless of their intended major.
Yes! It is a fun way to learn more about academic writing

I would definitely recommend this course to all students, regardless of whether you consider yourself a "writer" or not, but especially to those students who maybe don't have as much confidence in their own writing skill. I felt like the course was a very good introduction to "college-style writing" and certainly did a lot to help me prepare for future writing.

I would 100% recommend this course to another student! Overall, this course was a great introduction to college-level writing. The material was interesting, the grading was very fair, and Prof. Ringel-Ensley was a wonderful professor. She was kind, funny, and relatable, she was very skilled at facilitating class discussion, and she gave very thorough and high-quality feedback that improved the quality of my writing and also the quality of my thinking.
